title: Results of my Master’s Thesis
text:
Opium Cultivation
I expected a positive difference-in-difference effect for districts with pre-takeover opium poppy cultivation.
In general, I defined a district as poppy-cultivating if UNODC estimates indicated a cultivation area greater than 0 hectares in 2020.

The variables ‘treated’ and ‘post’ have been removed because of collinearity. 


Poppy districts are defined as every district > 0 ha poppy cultivation.


Warning: Removed 6 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range
(`geom_text()`).









To test wether wether the intensity of poppy cultivation per district played a role I tested different definitions of poppy cultivation by varying the cutoff for when the binary treatment variable equals one. For the relative cutoffs, I divided the absolute poppy cultivation area of each district by its area of irrigated land.









Across all relative cutoffs there is no significant effect after Taliban takeover. For some cutoffs, significant coefficients appear in 2018 and 2019. This could point to different pre trends for districts with higher share of poppy cultivation.

















Poppy Ban
On April 3 2022 the de-facto government announced a ban on Opium poppy cultivation with a two-month grace period covering the ongoing harvest.  Because of the grace period, it can be argued that the 2022 harvest was largely unaffected even though the ban was already announced. Farmers shifted towards wheat cultivation from the beginning of the sowing season around October and November 2022 . Because 80% of the opium harvest is sold by farmers within the same year it is likely that economic effects are seen in the next harvest season of 2023 .
Hence, I test two alternative event times of the ban: 2022 and in 2023.
I expect a negative difference-in-diffrence effect on districts which cultivated opium poppy before the ban (became effective).

Quarters 1 and 2 after the Taliban takeover show a positive effect, weakly significant (10%) effect.





Taliban Control
During the NATO mission, Afghanistan was never fully under the control of the Afghan government and its allies. I expect a positive difference-in-differences effect for districts that were already under Taliban control as of April 8, 2021 as I assumed these districts would experience less (economic) disruption.


Yearly DiDYearly EvStQuarterly EvSt


                          did_tali
Dependent Var.: ln_ntl
tali_cont_bin x post = 1 0.005 (0.004) Fixed-Effects: ————- GID_2 Yes year Yes ________________________ _____________ S.E.: Clustered by: GID_1 Observations 984 R2 0.97957 Within R2 0.00030 — Signif. codes: 0 ‘’ 0.001 ’’ 0.01 ’’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ’ ’ 1 did_tali



























NATO Installations
The NATO mission had installations in various districts across Afghanistan. I expect a negative difference-in-differences effect for districts with prior NATO installations, as these areas are likely to experience a greater change in the local economy due to the withdrawal of foreign forces and aid.

The negative effects in 2021 and 2022 are significant at the 10% level.

title: Quarterly Results of my Master’s Thesis
text:
This document presents the results of the quarterly event studies conducted for my Master’s Thesis using different specifications of fixed effects (FE).
During my final presentation, we discussed whether I had employed yearly instead of quarterly fixed effects in order to better isolate the effects of my hypotheses from potential seasonal variations.
Upon reviewing my code, I found that I had used time-unit fixed effects, meaning that each quarter was treated as a separate time period rather than as the same quarter across years. Therefore, I additionally experimented with specifications including (i) quarter fixed effects independent of the year and (ii) both quarter and year fixed effects simultaneously.

title: Corrected Quarterly Results of my Master’s Thesis
text:
Urbanity
To understand whether the (NATO) effects are partly driven by urban–rural differences, I create a measure of “urbanity” using VIIRS Nighttime Lights.
For each district, I take the maximum quarterly radiance value (max_ntl) and place it in the percentile distribution of all districts. 






I then define three categories:

major_urban: top 5% brightest districts
mid_urban: 5% - 15% brightest districts
rural: all remaining districts


Descriptive pattern: Urbanity and NATO presence
The table below shows how many observations in each group are NATO-treated.
This is useful to see whether the treatment is spatially concentrated.

title: Corrected Quarterly Results of my Master’s Thesis
text:
Urbanity as fixed effect
I created an urbanity category as explained before.









event_model_quart_nato_urbanFE <- feols(
  ln_ntl ~ i(event_time, any_military, ref = -1) |
    GID_2 + time_id + urban_category,
  data    = did_data_quart_nato,
  cluster = ~GID_1
)
